sources.title: Network (1976)
sources.description: Network , directed by Sidney Lumet, is a satirical drama that critiques the television industry and explores themes of media manipulation, corporate greed, and the loss of moral integrity in journalism.The film follows Howard Beale, an aging news anchor played by Peter Finch, who suffers a mental breakdown on air after being told he will be fired. His outburst, in which he tells viewers to get out of their houses and scream, turns him into a sensational TV personality.The network executives, represented by the ambitious Diana Christensen (Faye Dunaway), exploit Beale's mental state to boost ratings. They capitalize on his outrageous behavior, turning him into a media spectacle while ignoring the ethical implications.Beale's rise comes with consequences, including the moral decay of journalism. His unhinged rants gain a devoted following, making him a prophet-like figure, while the network faces increasing pressure to prioritize sensationalism over integrity.The film culminates in a shocking conclusion where corporate interests ultimately decide Beale's fate, reflecting the ruthless nature of media and the loss of genuine news reporting.

metadata.Plot: In the 1970s, terrorist violence is the stuff of networks' nightly news programming and the corporate structure of the UBS Television Network is changing. Meanwhile, Howard Beale, the aging UBS news anchor, has lost his once strong ratings share and so the network fires him. Beale reacts in an unexpected way. We then see how this affects the fortunes of Beale, his coworkers (Max Schumacher and Diana Christensen), and the network.
metadata.Actors: Faye Dunaway, William Holden, Peter Finch
